Use the following rules of inference: existential instantiation, universal
instantiation, disjunctive syllogism, modus tollens and existential
generalisation to show that:

$If:$
    * Hypothesis 1: $\forall x(P(x)\lor Q(x))$
    * Hypothesis 2: $\forall x(\lnot Q(x)\lor S(x))$
    * Hypothesis 3: $\forall x(R(x)\rightarrow\lnot S(x))$
    * Hypothesis 4: $\exists x\lnot P(x)\ are\ true$
     
$Then: \exists x\lnot R(x)\ is\ true$
---------------------------------------------------------------
MY ANSWER BELOW THIS POINT
---------------------------------------------------------------

* Hypothesis 1: $\forall x(P(x)\lor Q(x))$

* Hypothesis 2: $\forall x(\lnot Q(x)\lor S(x))$
     
* Hypothesis 3: $\forall x(R(x)\rightarrow\lnot S(x))$
 
* Hypothesis 4: $\exists x\lnot P(x)\ are\ true$

5.) $\lnot P(x)$                <--$4,\ Existential\ instantiation$
6.)$P(x)\lor Q(x))$             <--$1,\ Universal\ Instantiation$
7.) $Q(x)$                      <--$5,\ 6,\ Disjunctive\ syllogism$
8.)$\lnot Q(x)\lor S(x)$        <--$2,\ Universal\ Instantiation$
9.)$S(x)$                       <--$7,\ 8,\ Disjunctive\ syllogism$
10.)$R(x)\rightarrow\lnot S(x))$<--$3,\ Universal\ Instantiation$
11.) $\lnot R(x)$               <-- $9,\ 10,\ Universal\ modus\ tollens$
12.)$\exists x \lnot R(x)$      <-- $11,\ Existential\ generalization$
$Then: \exists x\lnot R(x)\ is\ true$
